title: P05-2013

sentences.text: This paper presents the results of automatically inducing a Combinatory Categorial Grammar -LRB- CCG -RRB- lexicon from a Turkish dependency treebank .
The fact that Turkish is an agglutinating free word order language presents a challenge for language theories .
We explored possible ways to obtain a compact lexicon , consistent with CCG principles , from a treebank which is an order of magnitude smaller than Penn WSJ .

Entity-ccg_principle.label: CCG principles
Entity-ccg_principle.description: Principles governing Combinatory Categorial Grammar (CCG) theory, guiding the construction and organization of a lexicon.

Entity-the_fact.description: A characteristic or property of Turkish as a language, specifically its nature as an agglutinating and having free word order.

Entity-combinatory_categorial_grammar.label: Combinatory Categorial Grammar
Entity-combinatory_categorial_grammar.description: A linguistic theory that combines categorial grammar with combinatorial principles to analyze sentence structure and meaning.

Entity-treebank.description: A collection of annotated linguistic examples or texts used to train and evaluate natural language processing models.

Entity-ccg.label: CCG
Entity-ccg.description: A linguistic framework that proposes a compositional approach to grammar and semantics.

Entity-lexicon.label: lexicon
Entity-lexicon.description: A collection of words and their meanings, often organized in a systematic way.

Entity-turkish.label: Turkish
Entity-turkish.description: A Turkic language spoken primarily in Turkey and Cyprus.

Entity-penn_wsj.label: Penn WSJ
Entity-penn_wsj.description: A widely used corpus or dataset in natural language processing and linguistics

Entity-language_theory.label: language theories
Entity-language_theory.description: A set of concepts or frameworks used to explain and analyze linguistic phenomena, including aspects such as grammar, syntax, semantics, and pragmatics.

Entity-fact.label: fact
Entity-fact.description: A piece of information or observation, often used to describe a discovery or insight.

summary: This paper presents the results of automatically inducing a Combinatory Categorial Grammar -LRB- CCG -RRB- lexicon from a Turkish dependency treebank . The fact that Turkish is an agglutinating free word order language presents a challenge for language theories . We explored possible ways to obtain a compact lexicon , consistent with CCG principles , from a treebank which is an order of magnitude smaller than Penn WSJ .

Predicate-presents.label: presents
Predicate-presents.description: The predicate 'presents' indicates that the subject provides or offers information, ideas, or concepts to others through its object. The connection between the subject and object suggests a relationship of exposition, introduction, or explanation.

Predicate--induces-.label: -induces-
Predicate--induces-.description: -induces- connects a linguistic theory or framework (subject) with a specific dataset or resource (object), indicating that the former induces or generates the latter, often through some form of annotation or parsing process.

Predicate-explored.label: explored
Predicate-explored.description: To explore something means to investigate or examine it thoroughly, often seeking new insights, understanding, or possibilities. The subject of the predicate has engaged in a systematic and deliberate process of discovery, analysis, or investigation to gain knowledge about the object.

Predicate-consistent_with.label: consistent with
Predicate-consistent_with.description: Indicates that the subject and object share similarities or characteristics that align with each other. The predicate 'consistent with' suggests a match between the subject's properties, principles, or patterns and those found in the object.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' indicates that the subject is a specific instance or member of a more general category or class denoted by the object. It establishes a hierarchical relationship between the subject and the object, where the subject is a narrower or more specialized concept within the scope of the object.
